title: Kenya: Set Your Sights Higher, Collymore Tells Entrepreneurs
text:
Zambia: U.S. to Set Up Entrepreneurship Centre in Zambia 
The Safaricom CEO decried the lack of start-up capital and said bigger companies could do more to support smaller businesses, including making available resources that they could use. 
Mr Takunda Chingonzo, co-founder of Zimbabwean Internet company Saisai Wireless, said large firms and start-ups are often unable to work together, because smaller ones often try to disrupt the business environment, instead of being a client to established business. 
He said many entrepreneurs fear larger companies will steal their ideas. Mr Collymore drew great applause when he agreed that this mind-set needs to change. 
The session dwelt heavily on the need to see entrepreneurship as more than technology, the need to increase connectivity and the problems entrepreneurs go through when starting businesses. 
Mr Chris Daniels, a vice president of product for Facebook said the three hurdles holding back people from making maximum use of the Internet are access, affordability and awareness. 
"Connectivity is foundational to entrepreneurship," he said. "When you show people how the Internet can help them, they will pay for it. They are already paying for voice and text." 
Mr Larry Alder, a director of access development at Google advised entrepreneurs to seek as much benefit as they could from new trends in technology. 
"When a wave such as the Internet comes, ride it all the way to the beach." 
He gave a glimpse of future trends that Facebook and Google are working on to make broadband Internet available to mobile handsets. Kenya
